sen.j: 四納言（しなごん）とは、平安時代中期一条天皇の時代に活躍した4人の公卿（源俊賢・藤原公任・藤原斉信・藤原行成）の称。
sen.e: Shinagon is a denomination referring to the four court nobles (MINAMOTO no Toshikata, FUJIWARA no Kinto, FUJIWARA no Tadanobu, and FUJIWARA no Yukinari), who were active in the era of Emperor Ichijo in the middle Heian Period.

Shinagon refers to the four court nobles (MINAMOTO no Toshikata, FUJIWARA no Kinto, FUJIWARA no Tadanobu, and FUJIWARA no Yukinari) who were active in the era of Emperor Ichijo in the middle Heian Period.

"Shinagon" refers to the four court nobles (MINAMOTO no Toshikata, FUJIWARA no Kinto, FUJIWARA no Tadanobu, and FUJIWARA no Yukinari) who were active in the era of Emperor Ichijo in the middle Heian Period.

sen.j: 「恪勤」には職務に精励するとともに、高官に仕える身分の低い従者（侍）の意味を持っており、実資は右衛門督（藤原斉信）以下の上達部（公卿、ここには俊賢・公任・行成を含む）が左府（左大臣藤原道長）の従者に成り下がったと嘲笑したと解されている。
sen.e: "Kakugon"(恪勤) means a lower-ranked retainer (samurai) who serves for a high rank official, while dedicating himself in his duties,' and this comment can be interpreted that Sanesuke was ridiculing, saying that Saemon no kami (captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) FUJIWARA no Tadanobu, and other Kandachimes (上達部) (court nobles, including Toshikata, Kinto, Yukinari in this context) had come down to be mere retainers of Safu (left ministry) (Sadaijin (minister of the left) FUJIWARA no Michinaga).

sen.e: And the reason why Sanesuke, although called 'Kenjin Ufu' (Wise Right Ministry), was not included in Shinagon that was supposed to symbolize the men of wisdom, owed largely to the fact that Sanesuke was in a position that might threaten the power and influence of Michinaga, because Sanesuke was a person of wisdom with a vast knowledge of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquettes) and, moreover, a legitimate son of the Ononomiya family line.
